message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Hydrogen peroxide works as a disinfectant by forming free radicals through a process called oxidation, which can damage and kill microorganisms. None of the other options are mechanisms of action of hydrogen peroxide.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Hydrogen peroxide releases oxygen gas, which acts as a free radical and disrupts cell membranes and microbial proteins, ultimately killing microorganisms. Therefore, the most likely mechanism of action of hydrogen peroxide is the formation of free radicals.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Hydrogen peroxide is an oxidizing agent that forms free radicals, which damages the cell membranes and proteins of microorganisms. This mechanism of action makes it an effective disinfectant.
We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Hydrogen peroxide acts as an oxidizing agent and forms free radicals, which damages the cell membrane and kills microorganisms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on hydrogen peroxide for help. Hydrogen peroxide disinfects by releasing free radicals, which can enter microbial cells and cause damage to their DNA and other components. This leads to cell death and helps to prevent infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Hydrogen peroxide is a disinfectant that works by forming free radicals, which can damage bacterial cell membranes and kill the bacteria. This mechanism of action is also why hydrogen peroxide can cause mild tissue damage and delay wound healing if used inappropriately. Halogenation of nucleic acids and crosslinking of proteins are not mechanisms of action for hydrogen peroxide. Congealing of cytoplasm is not a recognized mechanism of action for any disinfectant.
We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Hydrogen peroxide works as a disinfectant by releasing oxygen and forming free radicals that can destroy bacteria and viruses.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Hydrogen peroxide works by forming free radicals, which can damage bacterial DNA and other cellular components leading to their death. Halogenation of nucleic acids requires the use of halogenating agents such as iodine, while crosslinking of proteins requires the use of aldehydes such as formaldehyde. Congealing of cytoplasm is not a mechanism of action for hydrogen peroxide.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Hydrogen peroxide functions as a disinfectant by forming free radicals that destroy cell membranes and components. Halogenation of nucleic acids and congealing of cytoplasm are not mechanisms of action of hydrogen peroxide. Crosslinking of proteins is a mechanism of action of some disinfectants, but not hydrogen peroxide.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Hydrogen peroxide works as a surface disinfectant by releasing oxygen free radicals which damage the cell membranes of microorganisms, leading to their destruction. Therefore, the correct answer is (C) formation of free radicals. Options (A), (B), and (D) are not relevant mechanisms of action for hydrogen peroxide.
